items.purpose_in_article: To analyze expression profiles of monolignol biosynthetic genes across various tissues.
items.key_output: Tissue-specific expression profiles used for clustering and TGMI analysis.
items.notes: Includes tissues from buds, catkins, leaf, root and stem.

items.species_or_material: P. tremula cambial growth and wood formation
items.purpose_in_article: To analyze expression profiles of monolignol biosynthetic genes during wood formation.
items.key_output: High-resolution spatial expression profiles (phloem, cambium, expanding/maturing xylem) used for TGMI analysis.
items.notes: Micro meter-scale profile.

items.purpose_in_article: To identify transcriptional regulators of lignin biosynthesis from high-throughput gene expression data.
items.key_output: A regulatory network identifying known (e.g., NAC, MYB) and novel TFs correlated with monolignol biosynthetic genes.
items.notes: Novel algorithm that calculates mutual interaction for a TF and two pathway genes.

items.purpose_in_article: Cited as a method for discovering novel regulators and mechanisms in lignin biosynthesis.
items.key_output: Identified a defense-related HCT2 regulated by WRKY TFs.
items.notes: Also mentions eQTL/eQTN studies.

items.purpose_in_article: Cited as a method to show direct binding of a TF to a promoter.
items.key_output: Showed that MYB46 directly binds to the promoters of PAL.
items.notes: Mentioned in the context of previous literature.

items.purpose_in_article: Cited as a method to show TF binding to promoters.
items.key_output: Revealed SNBE and AC elements as NAC and MYB binding motifs.
items.notes: Also known as EMSA.

citations.quote: ...based on the Populus Gene Expression Atlas database (different tissues of... P. trichocarpa, 72 RNA-Seq libraries)... and AspWood database (micro meter-scale profile of P. tremula... 137 RNA-Seq libraries)
citations.section: The monolignol biosynthesis pathway in Populus.

citations.quote: In this review, we also applied the TGMI algorithm to identify regulators of lignin biosynthesis in Populus based on the tissue-specific Populus Gene Expression Atlas and AspWood datasets (209 RNA-Seq samples in total).

citations.quote: A recent study using genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL)/expression quantitative trait nucleotide (eQTN) studies identified a defense-related HCT2 that was regulated by WRKY TFs...
citations.section: Regulatory network generated by triple-gene mutual interaction (TGMI) algorithm...

citations.quote: Electrophoretic mobility shift assay and chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis showed that MYB46 directly binds to the promoters of PAL (Kim et al., 2014).
citations.section: Regulatory network generated by triple-gene mutual interaction (TGMI) algorithm...

items.limitation_or_gap: Some previously reported lignin pathway regulators were missing from the TGMI analysis.
items.proposed_future_work: Investigate multiple datasets, pooled from various tissues types during specific rapid developmental processes.
items.notes: Attributed to potentially limited data in the current analysis.

items.limitation_or_gap: Need for discovery of novel regulators and mechanisms.
items.proposed_future_work: Use of GWAS and eQTL/eQTN analyses to provide further supportive lucidity.
items.notes: These methods are suggested to help in discovering new regulatory elements.

items.limitation_or_gap: Lack of experimental evidence for some predicted regulatory relationships.
items.proposed_future_work: Experimental evidence will be required to verify this regulatory relationship.
items.notes: Example given for predicted regulation of COMT2 by HD-ZIP and LBD family TFs.

items.limitation_or_gap: Uncertainty if certain TFs directly regulate target genes.
items.notes: Example given for whether WRKY directly regulates CSE in Populus.

items.proposed_future_work: The underlying regulatory mechanism remain unverified.
items.notes: While studies imply potential roles of lncRNAs in lignin biosynthesis, the mechanism is not yet confirmed.

items.species_or_material: Eucalyptus gunnii EgCAD2 promoter in transgenic tobacco
items.purpose_in_article: To identify the minimal regulatory region of the promoter required for vascular expression.
items.key_output: Delineated an 80 bp regulatory region [-203/-124] necessary for expression in xylem and vascular cambium.
items.notes: Used several truncated versions of the promoter fused to a GUS reporter gene.

items.purpose_in_article: To precisely map protein-DNA interaction sites on the EgCAD2 promoter.
items.key_output: Identified two protected areas (BSa and BSb) and surrounding hypersensitive sites within the 80 bp regulatory region.
items.notes: Dimethyl sulphate (DMS) methylates unprotected guanine residues.

items.purpose_in_article: To investigate the functional role of putative cis-elements by introducing block mutations.
items.key_output: Created promoter versions with mutated MYB and BS elements for use in EMSA, transactivation, and transgenic plant assays.

items.species_or_material: Recombinant EgMYB2 protein and tobacco protein extracts
items.purpose_in_article: To test the in vitro binding of proteins to wild-type and mutated promoter fragments.
items.key_output: Showed that MYB sites in both promoters are crucial for binding of EgMYB2 and for the formation of specific DNA-protein complexes with cellular extracts.

items.purpose_in_article: To test the ability of a TF (EgMYB2) to activate gene expression from the target promoters.
items.key_output: Demonstrated that EgMYB2 activates both EgCAD2 and EgCCR promoters, and this activation is dependent on intact MYB binding sites.
items.notes: Co-transfection of effector (TF) and reporter (promoter-GUS) constructs.

items.purpose_in_article: To investigate the in planta role of each cis-element on tissue-specific promoter activity.
items.key_output: Showed that the MYBb element is crucial for overall vascular expression of EgCAD2, while the BSb element is important for expression in the cambial zone.

citations.quote: By using promoter deletion analysis and in vivo footprinting, we identified an 80 bp regulatory region in the Eucalyptus gunnii EgCAD2 promoter...
To precisely map the cis-elements in the EgCAD2 promoter interacting with trans-acting factors, we used in vivo dimethyl sulphate (DMS) footprinting...
A directed mutagenesis approach was used to introduce block mutations in all putative cis-elements of the EgCAD2 promoter and in those of the 50 bp regulatory region...
We showed that the conserved MYB elements in EgCAD2 and EgCCR promoters are crucial both for the formation of DNA-protein complexes in EMSA experiments and for the transcriptional activation...

items.limitation_or_gap: The functional role of the MYBa cis-element in the EgCAD2 promoter is unclear.
items.notes: Experiments did not provide clear evidence for its function, though it may bind a repressor or be active in contexts not tested (e.g., specific stimuli, woody plants).

items.limitation_or_gap: The specific transcription factors binding to the identified cis-elements in vivo are unknown.
items.proposed_future_work: Identification of the transcription factors that bind these cis-elements.
items.notes: The study used recombinant protein or whole-cell extracts, not identified native TFs.

items.limitation_or_gap: The interplay between transcription factors binding to the promoter elements is not yet understood.
items.proposed_future_work: Determine the mechanisms by which these transcription factors interplay with each other.
items.notes: The goal is to understand how TFs cooperate to provide spatio-temporal regulation.

items.limitation_or_gap: The role of EgMYB2 needs clarification regarding direct vs. indirect activation.
items.proposed_future_work: To determine whether EgMYB2 activates the transcription of these genes by direct binding on their promoters in vivo or by an upstream control...
items.notes: It's unclear if EgMYB2 binds directly in vivo or acts higher up in the cascade, like AtMYB46.

citations.quote: It is intriguing that neither EMSAs nor the transgenic plant approaches provided clear evidence of a functional role for MYBa in EgCAD2 promoter activity.
Future studies will aim at the identification of the transcription factors that bind these cis-elements and at the mechanisms by which these transcription factors interplay with each other...
At the present time, the role of EgMYB2 in the regulation of EgCAD2 and EgCCR gene expression must be clarified in order to determine whether EgMYB2 activates... by direct binding...

citations.quote: Stem cross-sections showed GUS expression in cells connected to lignification, such as differentiating xylem and parenchyma cells... but also in cells... such as the dividing cells of the vascular cambium...
GUS activity driven by the wild-type -119 EgCCR promoter construct showed a vascular pattern similar to that driven by the -203 EgCAD2 promoter...
Upon mutation of the BSb cis-element, a substantial decrease in GUS activity was observed in the vascular cambium and, to a lesser extent, in the immediately derived parenchymatous cells...
In contrast, mutation of MYBb resulted in a considerable global diminution of GUS staining in all vascular tissues, suggesting that MYBb could be bound by an activator factor...

items.purpose_in_article: To isolate specific cell types for gene expression analysis.
items.key_output: Showed that VND1-5 genes were specifically associated with xylem cells.
items.notes: Used with a PALM microlaser system.

items.samples_or_scale: At least 10 independent lines per construct
items.purpose_in_article: To determine the cell-type specific expression patterns of VND1 to VND5 genes.
items.key_output: Demonstrated that VND1-5 are specifically expressed in developing vessels.
items.notes: Used whole gene sequences (promoter, exon, intron, 3' UTR) for accuracy.

items.purpose_in_article: To test the ability of VNDs to activate promoters of target genes and the SNBE cis-element.
items.key_output: VND1-5 activated promoters of MYB46, CesA7, 4CL1 etc., and also activated the SNBE-driven GUS reporter.
items.notes: Used a dual-luciferase assay system for normalization.

items.purpose_in_article: To investigate the effects of inhibiting VND function on secondary wall deposition.
items.key_output: Dominant repression of VND3 resulted in reduced secondary wall thickening and a collapsed vessel phenotype.
items.notes: The VND3 coding sequence was fused with the dominant EAR repressor domain.

items.purpose_in_article: To test if VND1-5 are functional homologs of SND1.
items.key_output: Expression of VND1-5 driven by the SND1 promoter rescued the pendent stem phenotype and restored secondary wall formation in fibers.

items.purpose_in_article: To quantify the expression levels of VNDs, downstream TFs, and secondary wall biosynthetic genes.
items.key_output: Confirmed vessel-specific expression of VNDs and showed their overexpression induced a cascade of downstream genes.
items.notes: Used throughout the study for expression analysis.

citations.quote: Examination of their expression in laser-microdissected cells from stems revealed that VND1 to VND5 were specifically associated with xylem cells but not interfascicular fibers or pith cells...
To further reveal their expression patterns at the cell-type level, we generated VND-GUS reporter gene constructs and transformed them into wild-type Arabidopsis plants.

...we employed the transactivation analysis in Arabidopsis leaf protoplasts. It was found that VND1 to VND5 significantly induced the expression of the GUS reporter gene driven by the promoter of MYB46...
To further verify the functional roles of VND1 to VND5 in secondary wall biosynthesis, we employed the dominant repression approach...
To substantiate this hypothesis, we tested whether expression of VND1 to VND5 could complement the secondary wall defects in the snd1 nst1 double mutant.

items.limitation_or_gap: Differential roles and activation strengths of the various VND genes are not fully explored.
items.notes: The paper suggests VNDs may have differential roles or activation strengths, which could provide a mechanism to fine-tune cell wall composition, but this was not tested.

items.limitation_or_gap: The upstream regulation of the VND genes themselves is unknown.
items.proposed_future_work: Further investigation of how these VND genes are specifically induced during vessel development.
items.notes: Understanding the upstream signals that activate VNDs would enrich the understanding of vascular development.

items.limitation_or_gap: Discrepancy with previous reports on VND expression patterns.
items.notes: Authors resolve this by noting their use of whole-gene reporter constructs is likely more accurate than previous promoter-only constructs.

citations.quote: The possibility that VNDs may have differential roles in regulating secondary wall biosynthesis in vessels of different organs and have differential activation strength toward their target genes could not be excluded.
Further investigation of how these VND genes are specifically induced during vessel development will enrich our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying vascular development.
The discrepancy of VND expression patterns between this work and a previous report is most likely due to the VND sequences used for GUS reporter gene assay.

items.entity: SWNs (VND1 to VND5, VND6, VND7, NST1, SND1)
items.notes: VND1-5 overexpression induced MYB46/MYB83. SWNs are the top master switches.
Act as second-level master switches.
Overexpression of VNDs induced a suite of secondary wall TFs.
Overexpression of VNDs induced genes for cellulose, xylan, and lignin synthesis.
VNDs activate gene expression by binding to the SNBE sequence in target gene promoters.

citations.quote: In this network, a group of closely-related NACs, namely secondary wall NACs (SWNs), function as the top master switches capable of activating the entire secondary wall biosynthetic program...
Among the SWN-activated transcription factors, MYB46/MYB83 in Arabidopsis and their orthologs in other species act as the second-level master switches...

SWNs expressed in various secondary wall-forming cell types activate the second-level MYB master switches and other downstream transcription factors, which together activate secondary wall biosynthetic genes...

...they were found to be able to activate the same SNBE sites as SND1. These findings further corroborate the hypothesis that although different SWNs regulate secondary wall biosynthesis in different cell types, they all bind to common SNBE sites...

citations.quote: The VND1 to VND5 genes were shown to be specifically expressed in vessels but not in interfascicular fibers in stems.
The expression of VND4 and VND5 was also seen specifically in vessels in the secondary xylem of the root-hypocotyl region.
...the GUS staining for VND1 to VND5 was evident only in the developing vessels of protoxylem in elongating internodes...
Expression analysis showed that they were all expressed in various Arabidopsis organs, among which the stems exhibited the highest level of expression (Fig. 1C).

citations.quote: The first key enzyme in lignin biosynthetic process is the L-phenylalanine ammonia-lyase (PAL) which catalyzes a deamination of phyenylalanine to produce cinnamic acid...

All of the upsteam genes including L-phenylalanine ammonia-lyase gene (PAL4), 4-hydroxycinnamate:CoAligase gene (4CL5)... were found to be up-regulated in the transgenic plants overexpressed PtoMYB216...
Interestingly, the expression of ferulate 5-hydroxylase gene (F5H2) was significantly decreased in the PtoMYB216 overexpressors...
The results showed that Klason lignin content in stems of 35S:PtoMYB216 plants was almost 2-fold higher than that of the wild type...

items.purpose_in_article: To study the spatial and temporal expression pattern of PtoMYB216.
items.key_output: The PtoMYB216 promoter drove GUS expression in tissues undergoing secondary cell wall thickening, such as vascular regions.
items.notes: A 1.8-kb promoter region of PtoMYB216 was used.

items.purpose_in_article: To determine the subcellular location of the PtoMYB216 protein.
items.key_output: The PtoMYB216-GFP fusion protein accumulated in the nucleus.
items.notes: Used Gene Gun for transformation.

items.purpose_in_article: To test if PtoMYB216 functions as a transcriptional activator.
items.key_output: PtoMYB216 was able to induce the expression of the LacZ reporter gene, indicating it is a transcriptional activator.
items.notes: Full-length TF was fused to the GAL4 DNA-binding domain.

items.purpose_in_article: To quantify the transcript levels of PtoMYB216 in different tissues and to measure the expression of lignin/wall biosynthetic genes in transgenic plants.
items.key_output: Showed PtoMYB216 is highly expressed in xylem and that its overexpression alters target gene expression.
items.notes: Quantitative real-time PCR.

items.purpose_in_article: To measure the acid-insoluble lignin content in wild-type and transgenic poplar.
items.key_output: Stems of PtoMYB216-overexpressing plants had almost 2-fold higher Klason lignin content.
items.notes: A gravimetric method.

citations.quote: The 1.8-kb promoter sequence of PtoMYB216 was fused to the GUS coding sequence and introduced into wild-type A. thaliana. GUS expression was shown to be restricted to tissues undergoing secondary cell wall formation.
We assayed the subcellular localization of a PtoMYB216-green fluorescent protein (GFP) fusion in onion epidermal cells and found that the fusion protein accumulated in the nucleus...

To examine whether PtoMYB216 is transcriptional activators, we fused it with the GAL4 DNA-binding domain for transactivation analysis in yeast. It was shown that PtoMYB216 was able to induce the expression of the LacZ reporter gene...
The results showed that Klason lignin content in stems of 35S:PtoMYB216 plants was almost 2-fold higher than that of the wild type (Table 1)...

items.limitation_or_gap: Uncertainty whether PtoMYB216 is necessary for lignification due to potential functional redundancy.
items.proposed_future_work: Suppress several MYB family members simultaneously, focusing on the Arabidopsis AtMYB61 orthologues.
items.notes: Loss-of-function experiments on a single gene might not show a phenotype if other related genes compensate.

items.limitation_or_gap: The role of PtoMYB216 in other pathways, such as stress response, is unknown.
items.proposed_future_work: Future work will focus on understanding the function and regulation of this gene in biotic and abiotic stress responses.
items.notes: The paper acknowledges that lignin plays roles in stress responses, but PtoMYB216's involvement was not tested.

items.limitation_or_gap: The mechanism for regulating downstream genes without AC elements is unclear.
items.notes: Notes that C4H2 is activated despite lacking an apparent AC element, suggesting more degenerate elements may be present.

citations.quote: PtoMYB216 overexpression is sufficient to induce lignification, but it remains to be determined if it is necessary for lignification.
In order to address these problems in future experiments aimed at testing necessity... it may be necessary to suppress several MYB family members simultaneously...

It is still unknown whether PtoMYB216 also play regulatory roles in other biosynthetic pathways. Therefore, future work will focus on understanding the function and regulation of this gene in biotic and abiotic stress responses.

items.notes: Acts as a transcriptional activator of upstream lignin biosynthetic genes.
General mechanism mentioned where MYBs bind to AC elements in the promoters of target genes like PAL, 4CL, CCR, and CAD.

items.target: biosynthetic pathways of cellulose, xylan and lignin
items.notes: Mentioned as other poplar wood-associated MYB activators.
Activates genes for cellulose and xylan biosynthesis, suggesting a broader role in secondary wall formation.

citations.quote: Overexpression of PtoMYB216 specifically activated the expression of the upstream genes in the lignin biosynthetic pathway and resulted in ectopic deposition of lignin...
Previous studies have shown that R2R3 MYB transcription factors are involved in directly regulating secondary cell wall formation and lignin deposition by binding to AC elements in the promoters...
...the poplar wood-associated MYB transcriptional activators PtrMYB3 and PtrMYB20, activate the biosynthetic pathways of cellulose, xylan and lignin when overexpressed in Arabidopsis...

items.expression_pattern: Expressed in tissues undergoing secondary cell wall thickening.
items.notes: GUS expression also seen in vascular regions of roots, leaves, flowers, and siliques.

citations.quote: Quantitative real-time PCR analysis with different tissues further showed that the relative levels of the PtoMYB216 transcripts in the xylems were more than twice as abundant as in the phloems...

Stem sections revealed the GUS expression in protoxylem, metaxylem, intrafascicular cambium and fibers (Fig. 3). This restricted pattern of expression demonstrated that the PtoMYB216 gene was expressed in tissues undergoing secondary cell wall thickening.

items.notes: Overexpression of PtoMYB156 resulted in downregulation of PtoPAL1.
Able to significantly repress expression of the GUS reporter gene under the control of the PtrC4H2 promoter.
Repressed GUS expression from the PtrCESA17 promoter. CESA17 is a cellulose synthase gene.
Repressed GUS expression from the PtrGT43B promoter. GT43B is a xylan biosynthetic gene.

items.target_gene: lignin pathway genes (F5H2, CCoMOT1, C3H1, HCT1, LAC40, C4H2)
items.notes: Overexpression significantly downregulated a suite of lignin biosynthetic genes.
Expression of PtoKNAT7, a known transcriptional repressor, was induced in PtoMYB156 overexpression lines.
Overexpression of PtoMYB156 repressed several other secondary wall-associated MYB activators.

citations.quote: Overexpression of PtoMYB156 in poplar also resulted in downregulation of PtoPAL1 involved in phenylpropanoid pathway.
GUS activity assays showed that PtoMYB156 was able to significantly repress expression of the GUS reporter gene under the control of the PtrCESA17, PtrC4H2 and PtrGT43B promoters...

...the expression of these genes involved in the biosynthesis of wood components, including cellulose (CES17/18), xylan (GT43B) and lignin (F5H2, CCoMOT1, C3H1, HCT1, LAC40, C4H2), was significantly downregulated...

...the expression of several secondary wall-associated transcription factors, PtoMYB003/018/020/021/028/152, were repressed, while PtoKNAT7, a transcriptional repressor, was induced in 35S:PtoMYB156 lines...

citations.quote: Transgenic plants overexpressing PtoMYB156 also displayed a dramatic decrease in secondary wall thicknesses of xylem fibers and the content of cellulose, lignin and xylose compared with wild-type plants.
By contrast, knockout of PtoMYB156 by CRISPR/Cas9 in poplar resulted in ectopic deposition of lignin, xylan and cellulose during secondary cell wall formation.
...the expression of these genes involved in the biosynthesis of wood components, including cellulose (CES17/18), xylan (GT43B) and lignin... was significantly downregulated...

Quantitative RT-PCR analysis revealed that knockout of PtoMYB156 resulted in an increase in expression of secondary wall biosynthetic genes for lignin (PAL1, 4CL5, C4H2, COMT2, CCR2, CAD1), xylan (GT43B) and cellulose (CESA2B)...

items.purpose_in_article: To knock out the PtoMYB156 gene and analyze its loss-of-function phenotype.
items.key_output: Generated mutant alleles with small deletions/insertions, leading to ectopic deposition of lignin and increased expression of secondary wall genes.
items.notes: Used a multiplex genome targeting vector system with three sgRNAs.

items.purpose_in_article: To determine if PtoMYB156 could repress the promoters of secondary wall biosynthetic genes.
items.key_output: PtoMYB156 strongly suppressed GUS activity driven by the promoters of PtrCESA17, PtrC4H2, and PtrGT43B.
items.notes: An agroinfiltration method was used.

items.purpose_in_article: To determine the transcriptional activity of PtoMYB156.
items.key_output: The transcriptional activation activity of the VP16 domain was reduced when fused to PtoMYB156, indicating it has repression activity.
items.notes: Used a GAL4BD/UAS/LacZ system.

items.purpose_in_article: To quantify lignin content in wild-type and transgenic plants.
items.key_output: Lignin accumulation was significantly decreased (about 14.3%) in PtoMYB156 overexpressing plants.

items.purpose_in_article: To determine lignin monomer composition (S/G ratio).
items.key_output: The S:G ratio was not significantly changed in PtoMYB156 overexpressors.

citations.quote: To further analyze its genetic function, we used a CRISPR/Cas9-based reverse genetic system to knock-out the PtoMYB156 gene in the P. tomentosa genetic background.
GUS activity assays showed that PtoMYB156 was able to significantly repress expression of the GUS reporter gene under the control of the PtrCESA17, PtrC4H2 and PtrGT43B promoters...

...β-galactosidase assays showed that the transcriptional activation activity of VP16 domain was reduced markedly when fused to PtoMYB156 protein, indicating that PtoMYB156 has transcriptional repression activities.
The results showed that lignin accumulation was significantly decreased (about 14.3%) in stems of 4-month-old poplar plants.

items.limitation_or_gap: Direct binding of PtoMYB156 to target promoters was not demonstrated.
items.notes: The study showed repression of promoter activity in transient assays but lacked direct binding evidence (e.g., EMSA, ChIP).

items.limitation_or_gap: The detailed mechanisms of PtoMYB156 function remain largely unknown.
items.proposed_future_work: Needs to be further explored in the future.
items.notes: The paper provides functional evidence but acknowledges that the molecular details of its repressive action require more study.

citations.quote: However, direct evidence for binding of PtoMYB156 protein to the promoters of secondary wall biosynthetic genes is still lacking.
However, the detailed functions of PtoMYB156 to regulate secondary cell wall biosynthesis in poplar remain largely unknown and need to be further explored in the future.

items.notes: Acts as a negative regulator of genes for cellulose, lignin, and xylan biosynthesis.
Overexpression of the repressor PtoMYB156 leads to downregulation of known MYB activators, suggesting a higher level of control.
Induces the expression of PtoKNAT7, another known transcriptional repressor of secondary wall formation.
Mentioned as part of the established hierarchical network in plants that PtoMYB156 acts within.
Mentioned as second-level master switches in the established hierarchy.

citations.quote: Overexpression of PtoMYB156 in poplar also resulted in downregulation of PtoPAL1 involved in phenylpropanoid pathway.

In addition, the expression of several secondary wall-associated transcription factors, PtoMYB003/018/020/021/028/152, were repressed, while PtoKNAT7, a transcriptional repressor, was induced in 35S:PtoMYB156 lines...

A hierarchical network of transcription factors has been proposed to control secondary wall formation in plants. Several NAC... transcription factors including NST1/2, NST3/SND1, VND6/7 act as master switches...

items.expression_pattern: Lowest expression level.
GUS activity detected in all tissues, especially in vascular tissues.
items.notes: Histochemical GUS staining of transgenic Arabidopsis.

citations.quote: Expression pattern analysis showed that PtoMYB156 is widely expressed in all tissues examined, but predominantly in leaves and developing wood cells.
The PtoMYB156 was expressed in all the tissues tested, with the highest expression in old leaves and lowest expression in roots...
Transcript accumulation of PtoMYB156 was also detected throughout the stem, including xylem, phloem and bark.
...histochemical GUS staining showed that GUS activity was detected in all tissues of transgenic plants, especially in vascular tissues of roots, stems and leaf veins...
